name: The Good Food Institute
headline: Building a world where alternative proteins are no longer alternative.
description:
The Good Food Institute is a nonprofit working internationally to accelerate alternative protein innovation.

Globally, meat consumption is the highest it’s ever been. According to the UN, global meat production is projected to double by 2050.

With plant-based meat, cultivated meat, and fermentation, we can mitigate the environmental impact of our food system, decrease the risk of zoonotic disease, and ultimately feed more people with fewer resources. 

By making meat from plants and cultivating meat from cells, we can modernize meat production.

founders.name: Liz Specht, Founder/Senior Scientist
founders.description: Liz has a bachelor’s degree in chemical and biomolecular engineering from Johns Hopkins University, a doctorate in biological sciences from UC San Diego, and postdoctoral research experience from CU Boulder. She analyzes areas of technological need within plant-based and cultivated meat innovation and catalyzes research to address these needs. In addition to her role at GFI, Liz is a guest lecturer for Singularity University and a fellow at the Sustainability Innovation Lab at Colorado.

# Home
# Reimagining protein
## Modernizing meat production
The Good Food Institute is a nonprofit think tank and international network of organizations working to accelerate alternative protein innovation.
Globally, meat consumption is the highest it has ever been. According to the FAO, global meat production is projected to increase by as much as 50 percent by 2050.
With plant-based meat, cultivated meat, and fermentation, we can mitigate the environmental impact of our food system, decrease the risk of zoonotic disease, and ultimately feed more people with fewer resources. 
By making meat from plants and cultivating meat from cells, we can modernize meat production. 
GFI is building a world where alternative proteins are no longer alternative.
[![Icon plant based](https://gfi.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/icon-plant-based.svg)Plant-based meat](http://www.gfi.org/</plant-based>)
[![Icon cultivated](https://gfi.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/icon-cultivated.svg)Cultivated meat](http://www.gfi.org/</cultivated>)
[![Icon fermentation](https://gfi.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/icon-fermentation.svg)Fermentation](http://www.gfi.org/</fermentation>)
![An illustration of alternative protein production methods.](https://gfi.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/COM21019_defining-alternative-proteins-graphic_B-copy-1024x1024.png)
## What are alternative proteins?
Given how essential alternative proteins are to a global protein transition, the term itself needs to be universally understood, on the tip of more tongues, and at the top of more agendas.
[Learn more](http://www.gfi.org/<https:/gfi.org/defining-alternative-protein/>)

#### GFI around the world
GFI’s affiliates are working where we can have the greatest possible impact on the global food system. These countries and regions have robust scientific ecosystems and governments that are committed to using innovation to solve global problems. GFI operates affiliate organizations in six key countries and regions: Asia Pacific, Brazil, Europe, India, Israel, and Japan.
[Learn more about our global impact](http://www.gfi.org/</global>)

#### GFI Asia Pacific
GFI Asia Pacific is focused on advancing alternative proteins in the most populous area of the world, where both food production for export and scientific and agricultural innovation are growing rapidly.
[Learn more about our global impact](http://www.gfi.org/</global>)

[GFI Brazil](http://www.gfi.org/<#gfi-brazil>)

#### GFI Europe
GFI Europe is focused on advancing alternative proteins in Europe, which is home to much of the world’s scientific and commercial talent, and is one of the biggest potential markets for plant-based and cultivated meat.
[Learn more about our global impact](http://www.gfi.org/</global>)
[Visit Europe](http://www.gfi.org/<https:/gfieurope.org/>)
[GFI India](http://www.gfi.org/<#gfi-india>)
#### GFI India
GFI India is accelerating alternative proteins in what is on the cusp of being the world’s most populous country. India has world-class scientific institutions and a government that is committed to using alternative proteins to address malnutrition and as fuel for robust domestic economic growth.
[Learn more about our global impact](http://www.gfi.org/</global>)
[Visit India](http://www.gfi.org/<https:/www.gfi.org.in/>)
[GFI Israel](http://www.gfi.org/<#gfi-israel>)
#### GFI Israel
GFI Israel is focused on advancing alternative protein innovation in the “Startup Nation.” Israel is renowned for its innovative technology, entrepreneurial spirit, supportive government policies, investment capital, and support for basic research.
[Learn more about our global impact](http://www.gfi.org/</global>)
[Visit Israel](http://www.gfi.org/<https:/gfi.org.il/>)

### GFI Japan
GFI Japan is focused on securing greater government investment in alternative protein R&D and commercialization, supporting local regulators’ efforts to develop a clear path to market for cultivated meat, and facilitating new collaborations between Japanese research institutions and alternative protein scientists around the globe.

# Home
# Reimagining protein
## Modernizing meat production
The Good Food Institute is a nonprofit think tank and international network of organizations working to accelerate alternative protein innovation.
Globally, meat consumption is the highest it has ever been. According to the FAO, global meat production is projected to increase by as much as 50 percent by 2050.
With plant-based meat, cultivated meat, and fermentation, we can mitigate the environmental impact of our food system, decrease the risk of zoonotic disease, and ultimately feed more people with fewer resources. 
By making meat from plants and cultivating meat from cells, we can modernize meat production. 
GFI is building a world where alternative proteins are no longer alternative.

![Icon cultivated⟨114⟩Cultivated meat](http://www.gfi.org/</cultivated>)

Overview⟨129⟩
#### GFI around the world
GFI’s affiliates are working where we can have the greatest possible impact on the global food system. These countries and regions have robust scientific ecosystems and governments that are committed to using innovation to solve global problems. GFI operates affiliate organizations in six key countries and regions: Asia Pacific, Brazil, Europe, India, Israel, and Japan.
Learn more about our global impact⟨136⟩
![Gfi affiliate map3⟨137⟩]
GFI Asia Pacific⟨130⟩
#### GFI Asia Pacific
GFI Asia Pacific is focused on advancing alternative proteins in the most populous area of the world, where both food production for export and scientific and agricultural innovation are growing rapidly.
Learn more about our global impact⟨136⟩
Visit Asia Pacific⟨138⟩
GFI Brazil⟨131⟩
#### GFI Brazil
GFI Brazil is focused on advancing alternative proteins in Brazil, which boasts world-class agricultural universities and a government and corporations committed to feeding the world.
Learn more about our global impact⟨136⟩
Visit Brazil⟨139⟩
GFI Europe⟨132⟩
#### GFI Europe
GFI Europe is focused on advancing alternative proteins in Europe, which is home to much of the world’s scientific and commercial talent, and is one of the biggest potential markets for plant-based and cultivated meat.
Learn more about our global impact⟨136⟩
Visit Europe⟨140⟩
GFI India⟨133⟩
#### GFI India
GFI India is accelerating alternative proteins in what is on the cusp of being the world’s most populous country. India has world-class scientific institutions and a government that is committed to using alternative proteins to address malnutrition and as fuel for robust domestic economic growth.
Learn more about our global impact⟨136⟩
Visit India⟨141⟩
GFI Israel⟨134⟩
#### GFI Israel
GFI Israel is focused on advancing alternative protein innovation in the “Startup Nation.” Israel is renowned for its innovative technology, entrepreneurial spirit, supportive government policies, investment capital, and support for basic research.
Learn more about our global impact⟨136⟩
Visit Israel⟨142⟩
GFI Japan⟨135⟩
### GFI Japan
GFI Japan is focused on securing greater government investment in alternative protein R&D and commercialization, supporting local regulators’ efforts to develop a clear path to market for cultivated meat, and facilitating new collaborations between Japanese research institutions and alternative protein scientists around the globe.

generated_description:
**The Good Food Institute (GFI)** is a nonprofit organization founded in 2016, headquartered in Washington, D.C. It operates with a clear mission: to build a world where alternative proteins are the norm, not an alternative. This goal is increasingly critical, especially as global meat consumption reaches unprecedented levels—projected to double by 2050 according to the United Nations. 

GFI plays a pivotal role in accelerating innovation in alternative proteins, such as plant-based, cultivated, and fermented protein sources. These innovations are not merely trendy; they represent a necessary shift in our food system to mitigate environmental impacts, decrease the risk of zoonotic diseases, and enhance food security by enabling us to feed more people with fewer resources.

The organization is part of Y Combinator's Batch S18 and has grown to a team of about 110 employees. Their initiatives encompass extensive research and advocacy for sustainable food practices while fostering a global network dedicated to alternative protein solutions. They provide resources like a comprehensive solutions database, industry insights, research funding, and community engagement through platforms like GFIdeas, aimed at connecting entrepreneurs, scientists, and researchers.

GFI's focus areas include:

- **Plant-Based Meats**: Developing alternatives that use plants to recreate meat products.
- **Cultivated Meats**: Innovating techniques to grow meat directly from cells, reducing the need for livestock.
- **Fermentation**: Exploring how fermentation processes can generate protein-rich food options.

In essence, GFI is leading the charge towards a sustainable protein future, emphasizing collaboration on a global scale. The pathway is ambitious: to modernize food production systems and ultimately integrate alternative proteins into mainstream diets. 

For more information, you can visit their website at [gfi.org](http://www.gfi.org) and explore their extensive resources, studies, and initiatives aimed at revolutionizing the food industry.
